title.narrative: Management and Disposal of PCBs in Rwanda

description.narrative: Management and Disposal of Polychlorinated Biphenyls (PCBs) in Rwanda.

title.narrative: Management and Disposal of PCBs in Rwanda

description.narrative: The project aims at reducing environmental and human health risks from Polychlorinated Biphenyls (PCBs) in Rwanda.
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration
Minimizing environmental and health risks associated with PCBs though strengthening technical and regulatory capacity for the environmentally sound management and disposal of PCBs in Rwanda

Established and sustainable operational and regulatory capacity undertaking identification and management of PCBs in compliance with Stockholm Convention obligations by 2020
1. Legislation and guidelines adopted 2. Central warehouse with 350 tons of waste 3. Tonnage of PCBs safely disposed

comment.narrative:
NIP adopted based on preliminary knowledge of issue.
Absence of implementation capacity, either institutionally or physically.
Fragmented institutional responsibility for issue.
Unsafe poorly located (in wetland) storage facility for PCBs.

Functional regulatory regime covering import/export, identification, capture and securing PCBs for future disposal.
Operation capacity for ESM of current and future stockpiles and waste.
Informed PCB holders and qualified service providers to undertake PCB management activities.
Clear assignment of responsibilities within the government.

description.narrative: Outcome 1.2: RECO (principal PCB holder) and other possible holders are accessed to establish partnership scheme(s) for early/mature equipment replacement

Detailed inventory of PCB containing and contaminated equipment in service, existing PCB waste stockpiles and PCB contaminated sites in place end of 2011 Data management and tracking system operational and used for reporting end of 2011. Supply of lab equipment and consumables for the screening of 1200 units with staff trained in their use by 2011. Technical instructions on identification, sampling, data management

comment.narrative: Incomplete inventory of in service equipment and inventories of PCB waste stockpiles, cross contaminated equipment and contaminated sites. No formal consolidated PCB information system or associated reporting capability. Absence of capability to cost-effectively identify and categorize PCB contaminated materials acting as a major barrier to inventory development and tracking Currently no laboratory is equipped to specifically undertake PCB analysis No consolidated guidance available to holders of PCBs, relevant authorities or service providers on the practical primary management of PCBs.

Tracking system for in-service equipment, waste stockpiles and contaminated sites that will be maintained on an ongoing basis Publically accessible PCB information system operational, maintained, and used for reporting and information exchange under the Convention One accredited national laboratory capable of doing routine PCB analysis in soil, water and air samples inclusive of trained personnel and accessible to responsible regulatory authorities, PCB holders and service providers Screening capacity to effectively support tracking database as PCB management is undertaken into the future. Availability and application of technical instructions for management of current and future PCB inventories and tracking system

The national inventory of 2,344 electric transformers completed in 2014 indicated that 293 electric transformers were suspected to contain oil contaminated with PCBs. No capacitor was found to be contaminated with PCBs.
A total of 61 staff and technicians drawn from Rwanda Energy Group (former EWSA), REMA and Rwanda Standard Board (former Rwanda Bureau of Standard) were trained in October 2014 on how to sample and test for PCBs using the Chlor-N-Oil test kits, by the national consultant.
Using Chlor-N-Oil test kits 461 transformers were tested (which included 293 suspected transformer and 168 transformers that were not suspected) to confirm the contamination/non-contamination with PCBs.
Results of Chlor-N-Oil tests indicated that 151 transformers of the 293 suspected transformers which approximately weigh 498 tonnes are contaminated with PCBs of more than 50ppm. None of the non-suspicious 168 transformers contained more than 50ppm PCBs.
Draft ToR necessary to hire an international consultant to support in quantitative analysis have been developed and are now being reviewed before advertisement can be done (by October 2015).
The international consultant will provide technical support to the national laboratory of RSB to be able to undertake quantitative analysis of the oil of the 151 PCB containing transformers ( 50 ppm) as well as water and soil samples from around leaking transformers that contain PCBs ata concentration of more than 50ppm.
The data management tool (that was established by updating the 2005 PCB database) has been populated with the results of Chlor-N-Oil tests. The database provides information about contaminated equipment in operation, existing PCB stockpiles and contaminated sites. The database will continue to be updated on a regular basis by the Rwanda Energy Group (REG) limited (former EWSA). Plans are underway to make the database publicly available in REMA and REG websites once quantitative testing is completed.
Assessment of five national laboratories' capacities to undertake analysis of PCBs and other POPs chemicals has been done and a report has been prepared in September 2014. The report recommends measures for upgrading the five laboratories capacity to analysis POPs/PCBs in different media.
A guideline for regular inspection, monitoring and continuous updating of the PCBs inventory was produced and printed in 2015 and is being widely disseminated to REG and other PCBs holders.

description.narrative: Phase out program and disposal plan established by the end of 2011 Purchase of new transformers

comment.narrative: Phase out criteria limited to electricity supply and economical parameters
Availability and application of technical instructions for management of current and future PCB inventories and tracking system Reco staff technically able to manage disposal plan

An international consultant is being hired to review and improve the draft PCBs management and national disposal plan for the phasing-out of PCB oil and contaminated equipment that has been developed by a national consultant in September 2014.

description.narrative: 2.2: Developed and established rules to avoid cross-contamination of the oils and equipment; rules/procedures on handling contaminated oils/equipment and labeling

Regulations requiring registration, labeling and status reporting of potential all PCB and PCB containing materials in use end of 2010. Adoption of appropriate hazardous waste classification of PCBs and PCB contaminated materials in 2010. Enactment of legal ban on new use, re-use, trade, import, and export of PCBs and PCB contaminated equipment and materials in 2010. Legal measures allowing unrestricted regulatory access to information and locations that may have PCBs, (wastes stockpiles, PCB containing equipment and site contamination) in 2010

comment.narrative: No current regulations requiring declaration/reporting/unique identification by holders of presence of PCB waste stockpiles or PCB containing equipment. PCB waste classification not well defined in current waste management regulations allowing potential avoidance of proper management No regulation of PCB trade, use and import/export. Uncontrolled trade in contaminated PCB equipment occurs including export of stockpiles and waste and import of used PCB equipment. Re-Use of PCBs occurs. In appropriate declassification of PCB contaminated equipment occurs Legal barriers on the ability of authorities to inspect and access sites.

A comprehensive national regulatory registry of all PCB containing equipment in service that is maintained and updated such that its status and fate can be tracked Explicit inclusion of high concentration PCB wastes as priority hazardous wastes in national waste management legislation/regulations. Consistency of these with applicable international standards and the Basel Convention on trans-boundary movement of hazardous waste. Effective implementation and enforcement of use, re-use, trade, import and export bans including ensuring trade in scrapped contaminated PCB equipment and import of used PCB equipment is eliminated. Allowance in practice of access by mandated regulatory authorities to sites potentially containing or contaminated by PCBs, including rights to initiate assessment.

A PCBs Law, which provides the legal framework for the management, disposal and phase-out of PCBs in Rwanda in line with Basel and Stockholm Conventions provisions and requirements, has been developed and validated by the stakeholders.
The draft PCB law is currently being reviewed by the Rwanda Law Reform Commission before official submission to Ministry of Justice through the Ministry of Natural Resources for enactment into a law by the Parliament.
The draft PCB law defines legislation on: appropriate hazardous waste classification of PCBs and PCB contaminated materials; enactment of legal ban on new use, re-use, trade, import, and export of PCBs and PCB contaminated equipment and materials; legal measures allowing unrestricted regulatory access to information and locations that may have PCBs (wastes stockpiles, PCB containing equipment and site contamination).

description.narrative:
Legal measures related to the reuse of PCB oil and PCB contaminated mineral oil transformers
Legal measures on the handling, transport of dangerous chemical substances

comment.narrative:
No regulation on use and reuse of PCB oil and PCB contaminated mineral oil
No regulation for handling and transport of dangerous substances

Mitigation of cross contamination
Mitigation of risks of leakage and PCB pollution during transport and handling

description.narrative: 3.2: Promoted safe and proper equipment handling at holders; holders trained on leak handling, safeguarding and repairing of old/damaged equipment

Publically accessible information on PCBs and their management including: i) a maintained official web site; ii)a widely distributed brochure; iii) media exposure (two annual campaigns during project); iv) information events (two during project). Educational curricula related to chemicals (including PCBs) impacts on environment and human health, and management actions for addressing the issue during the project. Training and information seminars on chemicals management including PCBs for relevant government agencies, the academic community, affected communities, NGOs, and holders of PCBs ( 22 workshops)

comment.narrative: Low level of general awareness related to PCBs and chemicals management generally across all stakeholders. No current information products or programs. Limited active educational efforts or tools available. Key stakeholders generally have limited awareness of the issue or actions required of them to address it.

Widely accessible current information on PCBs and ongoing management activities. Integration into a national information program on sound chemicals management Inclusion of chemicals management and particularly PCBs in relevant educational programs, and active R&D interest in addressing it. Well informed stakeholder community engaged in addressing the issue with a high level of understanding and technical capacity.

REMA has produced a capacity building plan to raise public awareness of the environmental and health effects of exposure to PCBs.
A training manual and information dissemination materials (posters, brochures and flyers) for raising awareness about the health and environmental effects of exposure to PCBs have been developed and are now being disseminated in on-going public awareness campaigns. All downloadable tools will be made available on the REMA web site.
During this reporting period the following workshops/seminars have taken place:
1) A training of 32 journalists from 32 different media houses (Nov. 2014)
2) A training of 30 District Environmental facilitators, 25 representatives from REG Ltd, 5 REMA staff from the Department in charge of Environmental regulation and pollution control as well as a representative from RSB (Oct. 2014.)
3) 14 training sessions in 14 secondary schools in which 710 students and teachers (390 (55%) male and 320 (45%) female) across Western, Northern and Southern provinces were trained in June 2015.
4) A training of 55 staff from 55 NGOs dealing with Environment and Natural Resources across Rwanda were trained in June-July 2015. REMA’s department of environmental education and mainstreaming is currently spearheading the review of the education curriculum to ensure that environmental issues are incorporated in primary and secondary education. Chemicals management (including PCBs and POPs) are some of the new topics that will be proposed.
Collaboration between REMA and institutions of higher learning through this project has enhanced sensitization on POPs/PCBs among teaching staff. Institutions of higher learning are actively participating in the project steering committee and in the project technical team. This has contributed towards the department of Chemistry at University of Rwanda integrating sessions on POPs and PCB management in existing courses, and recommending the review of the curriculum on dynamic equilibrium for fourth year degree students to include Sustainable Chemical Management including POPs/PCBs.

description.narrative: Strategy and plan for pre-treatment and disposal of PCB stockpiles and wastes in place end of 2011. Development of standards and methodologies for ongoing identification and assessment of contaminated sites, inclusive of RECO staff to undertake it. Long term plan for the monitoring in place and phase out of PCB containing equipment in service consistent with Convention requirements (2025) formally adopted. Technical guidance and training available for handling, transport and safeguarding

comment.narrative: No plan in place to develop or access pre-treatment or disposal capacity exists for PCB waste stockpiles. No capacity exists respecting contaminated site clean- up generally and specifically with respect to PCB contamination. The phase out of PCB equipment is currently uncontrolled and includes practices such as selling/exporting PCB contaminated equipment for scrap, importing used PCB equipment for new or replacement installations, and replacing PCB oils in transformers to de-classify the equipment. No technical capacity available for handling, transport and safeguarding in the country

Comprehensive strategy and plan adopted, defining selection and the process of implementation of pre-treatment and disposal options both to be applied in the country (i.e. equipment decontamination, soil management, potential cement kiln utilization) and through export, including potential regional initiatives. Operational capability within responsible government agencies and/or commercial service providers to undertake assessment and clean-up of PCB contaminated sites consistent with international practice. A fully elaborated detailed plan endorsed by responsible authorities and PCB holders for replacement of in service PCB equipment identified in the detailed national inventory (Outcome 1), consistent with Convention obligations. Secure PCB handling, transport, storage operations

description.narrative: 4.1. Assessed existing locations for safe PCB equipment storage; 4.2. Collected PCB equipment / packaged oils and waste sent for storage location(s)
Secure storage capacity for PCB stockpiles and wastes at RECO sites for PCB material and PCB wastes by end of 2012 Operational rules for handling and transport adopted by RECO management

comment.narrative: No hazardous waste storage suitable for PCB waste stockpiles is available. No provision for secure storage at holders sites. No handling equipment and secure transport infrastructure available

1 national designated secure storage facility established in RECO premises and equipped with necessary infrastructure for PCB waste stockpiles under continuing care and custody of a responsible government authority. Major holders have secure storage facilities to accommodate PCB contaminated equipment when retired as an option. Mitigation of risks associated with handling and transport of PCBs

A central warehouse for safe storage of an estimated 500 tonnes of contaminated oil and equipment has been constructed and will be completed by end of July 2015. This warehouse is built on a land owned by REG, which is adjacent to a new power plant of the same company. This land had become unfit for living after the power plant has been built (particularly because of the noise coming for this power plant), and REG had organised expropriation of some inhabitants on that field and either relocation or financial compensation as per Rwanda's laws had been provided. It is important to note that this action happened prior to the allocation of this land for the PCB project and was not linked to it; no social grievance was reported/generated. REG Ltd which is the institution in charge of maintaining all electric transformers in Rwanda (both public and privately owned) will ensure safe storage of all Pure PCB/Askarel and PCBs contaminated oil (those in store and after decommissioning those in use) in the central warehouse before being de-chlorinated or disposed of at approved facilities.

description.narrative: Trained and equipped service providers capable of undertaking packaging, transportation end of 2010 Residual contamination cleanup for PCB solid wastes including training of RECO staff by end of 2010. Feasibility assessment and decision respecting cleaning of PCB containing equipment to allow recycling of metallic scraps Disposal of 150 MT of PCB stockpiles by export to a qualified disposal facility by 2012. Safety storage of 350 tons of solid wastes until recycling

comment.narrative: Limited trained capability in the safe handling of PCB contaminated materials and general absence of such capability among holders of PCBs and private service providers. Some PCB containing electrical equipment (transformers) are in critical applications and have long remaining service lives. Current practices involving replacement of oil do not meet international standards and result in retention of PCB contaminated equipment. No identified and secured stockpiles with most stockpiles likely being exported as scrap but leaving residual contamination in the form of waste materials and contaminated soils at unknown locations. No assigned responsibility for hazardous waste management generally and PCBs in particular.

Fully operational service provider capacity to support the securing of PCB waste stockpiles and transport to the designated national facility or export for disposal. Establish the feasibility of environmentally sound transformer decontamination locally as an option to replacement and export of large volumes of materials for ESM disposal Environmentally sound disposal of 150 MT of PCB oil and PCB contaminated mineral oil and local experience for future disposal requirements. .

REMA has requested UNDP to directly implement the activity related to elimination and disposal of PCBs contaminated oil and equipment in Rwanda. UNDP is therefore in the process of hiring an international consultant to provide technical support and advice on the best methods for elimination and disposal of pure PCBs (Askarel), cross-contaminated PCBs oil, and PCB contaminated soil and equipment in Rwanda. The international consultant will also support in tender documents preparation, procurement evaluation and contract management of a transportation/disposal company to undertake elimination and disposal of PCBs. The consultant will also provide advice and technical support to UNDP during hiring of a company to potentially undertake de-chlorination of PCBs contaminated oil (containing less than 10,000ppm) as well as the disposal of high content PCB oils (Askarel) at an approved facility before the end of the project.
